author: Liam Corless
title: Five candidates to replace Claudio Ranieri if Leicester sack their title-winning manager
text:
View gallery 
They're just one point clear of the relegation zone after a torrid start to 2017, in which they are yet to score a league goal but have conceded 12. 
Ranieri's heroics last season will surely buy him some time, but who could replace him if Leicester's owners end up giving him the axe? 
Here, we take a look at five contenders: Nigel Pearson Nigel Pearson (Photo: Chris Brunskill) 
They say you should never go back but if anyone knows what it takes to pull off a great escape it's Nigel Pearson. 
Leicester aren't quite in the same amount of peril they found themselves in two seasons ago when they won seven of their last nine matches to stay up, but in Pearson the Foxes would be appointing a man who knows the club and its players well. 
You can rest assured that there'd be plenty of comedic moments in the run-in too. Alan Pardew Alan Pardew (Photo: Dan Mullan) 
Crystal Palace sacked Alan Pardew in December thinking they'd be better off with Sam Allardyce at the helm. It's not quite turned out that way. 
Since Pardew's exit Palace have picked up a paltry four points from eight games and they now have an escape job of their own on their hands. 
The 55-year-old is not a manager you'd want in charge for a long-term project, but in the short-term he has previous for breathing new life into a club. Gary Rowett Gary Rowett (Photo: Nathan Stirk) 
Harshly sacked by Birmingham City last year, Gary Rowett has been out of a job since mid-December. 
He was doing a good job at St Andrew's when the Birmingham board decided it was a good idea to bin him and bring in Gianfranco Zola. 
Swansea were said to be seriously considering Rowett as a replacement for Bob Bradley before plumping for Paul Clement last month and Rowett is sure to be in Leicester's thoughts if Ranieri is canned. Mark Warburton Mark Warburton (Photo: PA) 
Mark Warburton is fresh on the market after his bizarre exit from Rangers over the weekend. 
Rangers issued a statement on Friday night announcing they'd accepted Warburton's resignation, before the Englishman sensationally came out and said he knew nothing about the statement and claimed he hadn't resigned. 
The following day Rangers' chairman, Dave King, revealed Warburton's employment was terminated because he wasn't committed to the club. 
Warburton had a 65% win percentage as Rangers boss and guided them to promotion back to the Scottish Premiership last season. 
Rangers failed to provide a credible title challenge to Celtic this season but, all in all, Warburton did a good job at Ibrox and it won't be long before he's back in the game. Avram Grant Avram Grant (Photo: Getty Images) 
Avram Grant is a man with Premier League pedigree and is available after resigning from his position as Ghana boss. 
He's managed Chelsea, Portsmouth and West Ham in England and knows his way around the top flight. 
In reality, he's the least likely to be considered out of the five managers in this list, but, then again, remember how much of a surprise it was when Ranieri was appointed as Pearson's successor in 2015? poll loading Will Claudio Ranieri last the season as Leicester manager? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
